title: ‘The Cheeseman’ is dead. Here’s what to know about him.
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Local News The reputed boss of the New England Mafia, Carmen “The Cheeseman” DiNunzio’s rise to the top was not without some hiccups.
Carmen Dinunzio listens to his attorney argue a motion to dismiss racketeering charges against him in state court on Oct.

title: South End restaurant named one of the most influential in U.S., according to Eater
author: Frances Klemm
bullets: Food News The restaurant "remains an essential Boston restaurant: still a party in a town that knows how it’s done,” according to Eater.
Paella Valencia at Toro in Boston's South End.

Dina Rudick/Globe Staff A South End restaurant, which features Spanish-style tapas, a curated wine list and cocktails, was recently named one of Eater’s most essential and influential restaurants in America over the past 20 years.

title: Zdeno Chara rejoins Bruins as Hockey Operations Advisor and Mentor
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Boston Bruins “Having played alongside Zdeno, I know firsthand the leadership, work ethic and professionalism he brings every day.
" Zdeno Chara is rejoining the Bruins in a new role.
Barry Chin / The Boston Globe By Conor Ryan September 25, 2025 | 2:39 PM 2 minutes to read Zdeno Chara is back with the Boston Bruins — albeit in a different role this time around.

title: How two Greater Boston secondhand stores stay on trend sustainably
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Business Covet and Found sell a curated collection of secondhand clothing items and some new, trendy accessories.
Clothing racks at Found in Cambridge.
Courtesy of Found ShareSend this article to your social connections.

title: 2 Boston coffee shops are named some of the best in the U.S., according to Yelp
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Food Though the East Coast didn't get as much love from Yelp reviewers as western states did, two beloved Boston coffee shops received some recognition.
Recreo Coffee in West Roxbury, MA Katherine Taylor for The Boston Globe ShareSend this article to your social connections.
Boston is a coffee town, no doubt about it.

title: Here is your New England fall weekend itinerary
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: Scenic Six Plus: Best cider doughnuts, apple orchard getaways, Topsfield Fair, and more.
The sunflower maze is shown at Lyman Orchards in Middlefield, Conn.

title: MBTA cameras will now be on the lookout for bus blockers — and issuing tickets
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Transportation Fines will be $100 for blocking bus stops and from $25 to $125 for blocking bus lanes.
An MBTA bus in Chelsea in 2023.
Pat Greenhouse/The Boston Globe ShareSend this article to your social connections.

title: Review: ‘One Battle After Another’ is an absolute masterpiece
author: Kevin Slane
bullets: Movie Reviews Paul Thomas Anderson's "One Battle After Another" is the director's most entertaining movie ever, an alchemic mix of political intrigue, thrilling action, and giddy comedy with Leonardo DiCaprio at the center of it all.
Leonardo DiCaprio in "One Battle After Another.
" Warner Bros.

title: Mass. brothers continue with flotilla aid mission to Gaza despite drone attacks
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Local News The two men are part of an international volunteer flotilla that faced three hours of attacks Tuesday night off the coast of Crete.
Two brothers from Massachusetts are continuing their humanitarian aid journey on the Global Sumud Flotilla despite drone attacks Tuesday night.

Mahmud Turkia/Getty Images By Darin Zullo September 25, 2025 | 1:33 PM 4 minutes to read Two brothers from Massachusetts are continuing their journey to Gaza as part of a flotilla carrying humanitarian aid after it was attacked Tuesday off the coast of Crete.

title: Future of Turtleboy’s witness intimidation cases uncertain amid allegations of doctored evidence, prosecutor’s withdrawal
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Crime “This case … at this point in time, is essentially stateless,” one of the blogger’s lawyers said Wednesday.
Aidan Kearney, the Massachusetts blogger who goes by the name "Turtleboy," at the first Karen Read murder trial at Norfolk Superior Court on Tuesday, May 28, 2024, in Dedham, Mass.
Stuart Cahill / The Boston Herald via AP, Pool By Abby Patkin September 25, 2025 | 12:25 PM 3 minutes to read ShareSend this article to your social connections.
